H0.text: A magnetic compass is the tool that best measures the distance an object travels after it is thrown in a class studying how gravity affects objects in motion.

H1.text: A meter stick is the tool best used to measure the distance an object travels after it is thrown in a class studying how gravity affects objects in motion.

H2.text: A calculator is the tool that would best measure the distance an object travels after it is thrown, as a class studies how gravity affects objects in motion.

H3.text: A stop watch is the tool that best measures the distance an object travels after it is thrown, as a class studies how gravity affects objects in motion.

A4.text: Metre-sticks are usually employed for work on a medium scale; larger than desktop work on paper, yet smaller than large-scale infrastructure work, where tape measures or longer measuring rods are used.

A5.text: Metre-sticks are especially common in the construction industry.

A6.text: Longer rulers (e.g. 18 in (46 cm)) are necessary in some cases, some examples being the yardsticks and meter sticks.

A7.text: Rulers are an important tool  in geometry, geography and mathematics.

A8.text: The length of the parabolic arc traced by a projectile, L, given that the height of launch and landing is the same (there is no air resistance), is given by the formula: L = v0^2/g( sinθ + cos^2θ ⋅ tanh−1 ( sinθ ) ).

A9.text: The time of flight for a projectile is given by t = 2 v0 sinθ / g.
